commentBody: Delightful!

That was breezy!

Good evening!

The week is off to a grand start! Today’s puzzle is whimsical and fun. Monday’s quotes puzzle (GEEZ LOUISE, WHOANELLY, etc.) and Tuesday’s animal foods puzzle (HORSERADISH, CRABAPPLE, etc.) were also creative and charming. Excellent diversions, along with the start of Wimbledon and Sunday’s start of the Tour de France. Thanks to all the constructors and editors!

Very clever theme. Loved figuring out the theme answers and the trivia the clues provided. 

A bit easy for a Wednesday, but the theme made it fun.
Navaho?
Very whooshy. The only resistance I met was a couple minutes trying to make a J for NAVAJO work with the cross.

Well, I liked it.  But I really thought I was going down early on the cross of 1D and 20A.  That was my ultimate entry.

I am very much uninformed about both the WWE and Non-American Football.  American football causes me some discomfort as well.

This was a puzzle that, as I was solving, was thinking "This is killing me, but I bet it's going to be considered easy."

8:45. 

Fun, tight theme and lively clues/fill today. 

Thanks for a great puzzle, Dan!
Fun and breezy puzzle for my morning commute! Love the clueing and the clever wordplay. I even have time to comment how much I like this one!

Writing board game questions is a trivial pursuit.

(Movie about it: "Postcards from the Wedge")
Seems really easy for a Wednesday puzzle.
Fun puzzle.  I was initially confused by GRAHjICDETAoL but once I got that sorted I was well below my Wednesday average. Thanks to the creators.

I don't know how long I stared at ICICLE in disbelief.  It just didn't seem right to me.

I know it is, but I so wanted something like "ice cycle".  But that didn't look right either.  In fact I knew it was one word, but I couldn't find a word that looked right.

Petrol, Francis is talking to himself again.  Might want to peek in on him to make sure he's not doing anything too embarrassing.

These were fun!

Did you know?! Many people mistakenly use “kilowatt” and “kilowatt-hour” interchangeably.

POWER POINT

I’m sure the other folks on our wordplay pub trivia team will have some more.

Easy peasy, lemon squeezy. 

PB for a Wednesday. 

Had NAVAJO before NAVAHO.

Really hard to come up with an alternative definition for banks that isn't geekily awkward (like "money supplier"). A bank is a bank is a bank.  I do like "modern aerosol emitter" though, it's wackily accurate; I guess a modern aerosol inhaler is a vaper! 

But I'm not going to give you NOIRS and I don't care what Barry or Steve say, parroting MW or wikipedia, who gives a flying hoot? No one I know calls them noirs and I'm not about to start. This is where I take my stand, on Mount Woolrich!*

What's that psychological mental move where you're upset about one thing, but focus your anger or frustration on something else instead? Like when you're somewhat peeved that the Senate just voted to give billionaires even more of a break while shutting down the country for everyone else, so you pick on NOIRS as a perfectly cromulent substitute for your ire? 

I'm thinking a "grand work" is more likely a "magnum opus" and not your garden variety opus. No one would mistake Beethoven's Opus 18 quartets for grand works, not like Opus 55, for example (Eroica symphony). So I put in EPIC at first, which gave me a fin fact (I thought "what's more leisurely than putting on your fins and going snorkeling?" but the other guy in my brain who replies to the first guy's dumb thoughts, said, "You've only gone snorkeling once, dummy, and you didn't find it that leisurely. Dope."

* after Cornell Woolrich


Love CARB crossing with the paleo diet, and that LABOR sits atop WOMB.

Mr. Caprera, you've rocked yet another cool puzzle, so I don't know what all this self-talk is about you not being cool. I adored it! So satisfying to solve! I, of course, also loved the sprinkling of music and music-adjacency all over the grid: The Sound of Music, TUBA, CELLI, OPUS, BLACK (Pearl Jam), IRA (Gershwin), IDINA, CHER, "at the COPA, COPAcabana..." And, of course, that BABY GRAND, because we wouldn't want to not think of Sir Elton John. Here he is, on his GRAND, singing one of his least well-known gems, chock-full of beautiful progressions: https://youtu.be/MHylaKT8S08?si=tdueurgytKY9qgh1 Thank you, Mr. Caprera, for a delightful puzzle in more ways than one!

This puzzle was a delight from start to finish, primarily because the clues gave you a toehold for the theme fills, then you had the teasing challenge of figuring out how it was going to work.  And I would say it all worked very well indeed.  For fills I didn't know, the crosses showed me that I did.  A lovely, fun, midweek breather from so much that isn't.

Thank you, Dan Caprera.  You came through once again.  I'm looking forward to another very soon!

Sometimes, I know all (or most of) the answers and get stuck because of poor spelling. When will I ever remember that Ms. Menzel is IDINA, not aDINA. I've seen her in "Rent." Heard her on the "Wicked" original cast recording. Belted with her to "Let It Go!" Speaking of "Frozen," I loved seeing IDINA crossed with ICICLE. Hey, maybe that will help me remember the I! Actually, now that I look over the rest of the puzzle, I realize that was really my only spelling error, and the other issues I had were from going too fast and making typos. I don't know why I'm compelled to race through early week puzzles instead of savoring them slowly. I think it's peer pressure. Hey, peers, stop pressuring me! Has anyone else played the board game KAZOO That Tune? My nephew got it for Christmas last year, and we had a lot of laughs with it. The description says you don't have to have any musical talent to succeed at it, but you do at least need to be able to carry a tune. Here a link to the game on the Strathmore Music Center website (because I'm not interested in supporting a particular billionaire), where my brother and I will be performing next week with the InterPLAY Orchestra, opening for Yellow Dubmarine. I'll link to that too for those in the DC area. It's a free concert, and I believe there will be food trucks! https://shop.strathmore.org/kazoo-that-tune-song-guessing-game/ https://www.strathmore.org/events-tickets/bloom-community-events/live-from-the-lawn-yellow-dubmarine/

Other than Issa RAE, you could have told me this crossword sat in a time capsule for 10 years and I would believe it.

Also — two Sound of Music clues?

Thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle. I’m a musician and an actress so I loved all those clues.

I will take issue with Navaho. While both Navaho and Navajo are used, the j usage is currently more accepted. I would actually like to see instead of Navajo, DIne accent over the e) used more often as that is how they refer to themselves. Navajo is way over used and wouldn’t it be better to be able to use a different clue than formally eating for dine?

Fun puzzle, Dan!  Hit a few snags, skipped around a bit, muttered a few bad words, but figuring out the theme was worth the struggle. Clever clues!  And thank you, Sam Corbin, for the whimsy and delight you bring to your Wordplay column. Not uncool!
Geeze Louise, went looking for my typo and it turns out I was chasing Amy.

I found this quite fun but very easy for a Wednesday. I got held up in the NE corner for a minute or two (my only gimme there was RISEN - I may be an atheist, but a well educated one 😉) - because of that I solved in Tuesday time rather than Monday. You'd think GRAPHIC DETAIL would be obvious, eh? Well, not when IrINA looks so much plausible than IDINA 🤣. Elsewhere I had to rely on crosses for both "The Sound of Music" entries.

YOUR LABOR ABUTS WOMB is an interesting sequence of words 🤣. TOFU OPUS could be a themed entry in some future puzzle 😆

Mildly FUN FACTs: I've never worn a TUX (but I might). I've never been to IBIZA (and given the reputation of the place, that will never change). I've never played a BABY GRAND piano, a TUBA, any CELLI, KENO or a game of PUB TRIVIA, but I've played TETRIS (well, duh) and been on a U-BOAT. I haven't smoked an E-CIG or eaten a BLT, but I love me some CARBs.
Am I the only one who had to know more about the movie in 23 across and found the Wikipedia entry and actually skimmed through the movie? 🫣

Such a fun puzzle! Thank you Sam Corbin for helping with the questioning clues that Mr. Caprera so cleverly conjured. I got the hang of it and they were lots of fun to decode. Wednesday puzzles are my favorite. Like the Bears' Beds, Wednesday's are just right. Not too hard and not too soft. I had to get the Sound of Music locale from the crosses. and even then I tried really hard to squeeze Alps in there somehow. But the crosses spelled it out clearly. My kinda game. Amy a WWE champ? You bet!  Can't wait for you to return with another one Mr. Caprera! 

Y'all have a great second half of the week and enjoy the 4th. We have a democracy to protect so eat lots of potato salad and watermelon. Don't scare the dogs, and be kind to one another. ✌️
Navajo.
Beautiful work. Enjoyed this one.

someone else may have said this, but humans haven’t existed for a million years. we’ve only existed for about 300,000. anything before that is a relative or ancestor, but not us. small thing, but slightly misinforming.
Cute theme, bit easy for a Wednesday but a fun 10 minutes
Isn’t it spelled NAVAJO?
As a native New Mexican... It's Navajo. Not NavaHo.     That deserves an apology

The antagonist of the sound of music is Herr Zeller, Rolfe Gruber ( emphasis on the E ) he’s a narrative obstacle at best, a betrayer archetype at worst.

Between getting the spelling of his name wrong and his actual part in the plot wrong that strikes me as sloppy

Delightful. 
Only one I didn't know - ACL - and the theme was good fun.

Avast mateys! A puzzle as fast and furious a me favorite barque the Maiden o' the Seas. Such fine lines and fulsome sails, there was no ship o' the line could catch 'er! We took so much booty in such a short time, we nicknamed her the Maiden o' the Sieze! Arrgh!
Thanks Dan. Most enjoyable.

Great theme! 

Here’s another FUN FACT …

Did you know?!  The oldest public park in the United States is in Boston

COMMON KNOWLEDGE

Ah but this constructor's Rough and Rowdy ways ARE cool. I was breezing along until I hit the southwest corner and BAM! I got snagged. Here I was thinking that this felt like a Monday puzzle. Delighted that I was wrong!

For once, I loved this puzzle! All those FUN FACTs. Got stuck for a few minutes when for some strange reason - since I do speak some French - I mistakenly thought 65A was Latin, which I do not speak. But came to my senses and got the answer without much delay.

The dog in today’s photo is just about to be kicked in the head! Never, ever pull a cow’s tail when they’re walking. Not if you prefer not to be a) battered or b) covered in excrement.

Back to the puzzle. A great theme, thoroughly enjoyable. Though I always thought the most common pub name was The Royal Oak. Haven’t checked it, but am willing to visit every pub of both names, purely in the interests of science of course. 

The heat wave has finally broken. The blessed relief of a cool breeze and grey sky. The alpacas are much happier and will be even more so if the shearer ever turns up.

Tell me if I am wrong about this.  Among the many subtle changes in the crossword puzzle in the last few months has been the excessive use of the blank in a clue. So many phrases would be better clues with some wit, word play or/ and deception that are now just fill in the space opportunity that requires nothing except familiarity. I don't know whether to blame this on automation in puzzle making or bad editing or both.

Can someone refresh my memory about how to get the Wordplay column to scroll when the comments are open? (I'm on a desktop). I haven't tried to do in a while, so I've forgotten how. I think it was Steve L. who originally provided that fix. Thanks.

Really clever puzzle - all in the clues. Quite a workout for me, and had to look up a couple of things, but then just a lot of working the crosses. Ended up being an enjoyable solve. Appropriate puzzle find today - another one all in the clues. I don't recall ever seeing another one like this. Anyway - a Sunday from September 26, 2001 by Bill Zais with the title: "Rational numbers." All of the theme clues were just an arrow pointing back at the clue number (and they were all down answers). Some examples: 11: "<-- :" ONEANDTHESAME "20 <-- :" SECONDTONONE "33 <-- :" THREEONAMATCH "53 <-- :" PIECESOFEIGHT "66 <-- :" ANEVENDOZEN And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/16/2001&g=86&d=A I'm done. ...
BUrLy for BUILT almost did me in.
Absolutely enjoyed this.  So much fun.

Thanks, Dan Caprera! I, too, am uncool which can occur in nerdy engineering & techie folks. Given that, the humor & knowledge among the commenters is such that I’d invite everyone to my dinner party! 

Enjoy your “Thursday” in this shortened USA work week.

Did you know? Everything is fine with everything 

FAKE NEWS

Oh, this is a terrific run-with-it theme.  Where the constructor finds a lovely language quirk, comes up with further examples, and it is so good that commenters pipe in with more.

Today’s brings an extra layer of fun with those interesting facts in the theme clues that whip up further comments.

Not to mention that the theme is quick to crack once the first theme answer is uncovered, and it is uber-fun to guess at the ensuing theme answers with as few crosses as possible.

Add beauty to the fun, with those two gorgeous long downs SABOTEURS and BABY GRAND. And an accidental beauteous word for me, who originally entered BURLY for [Muscular].

I, who appreciate being successfully misdirected, also liked going through rainbow-ish hues for that Crayola eight-pack, only to learn it was BLACK.  And, speaking of quirks – a backward ABUT crossing ABUTS!

Absolutely a mood lifter – thank you so much for this, Dan!
Glad others had a good time with this. My patience for this one ran dry very early on.

Word nerds unite!

I wear my badge proudly.

And this was a fun, 
how-have-I-not-noticed-that-phrasing-before?

But Dan did. And ran with it.
Fun solve, and overall a whimsy romp of a 
Wednesday.

What more could I ask for?

And, I hope it’s okay, but when I share
something with hubby or a friend about
our chats here, I call y’all my
Word Nerd World.

Which is one of the finest compliments 
I could bestow on our tiny nook in the 
inter-web-iverse.

Happy hump day all!
I liked it.  It was cute.
Very solid and fun to solve. Hats off to the puzzler.

Stop doomscrolling and put down your CELLI

A good one for all you folks who love factoids and trivia in your crosswords.

MUSICAL NOTE


Fun and factual puzzle.
I’m not quibbling with the clue, because it was indeed a fad at one time, but I just wanted to note that TETRIS is still played actively.  There are even tournaments!

Fun puzzle! but over too quickly:-( YMMV, but so many of the facts lay in my wheelhouse, that I was mainly hampered by my poor typing skills. This might have been a Wed. PB; 1:51 longer than what my stats say, but sometimes I think those times are a little whackadoodle. Good morning for films set in Austria. My main quibble: a baby grand (piano) is not a "step up" from an upright--they're two completely different designs. Besides the obvious difference in string and soundboard alignment, there are differences in mechanism--the most obvious one is how they handle the "soft pedal." But a good upright piano--a Yamaha YU series, say--is more costly, and in my opinion better, than a cheap grand. Here's Tykhon Shulyak and Vitalyi Kyianytsya performing the Sonata for Tuba and Piano by Paul Hindemith. The piano accompaniments for Hindemith's brass sonatas are notoriously difficult, and few pianists attempt them--Glenn Gould did a pretty good job; Mr. Kyianytsya does as well, although his piano looks a little short to me. (I wonder if that piano still exists?) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1SJw9FgEnW8&list=RD1SJw9FgEnW8&start_radio=1 Oh wait, there were 'celli in the puzzle as well! Here's Kim Namho not giving credit to the 'cellist or pianist, in a performance of the Love Theme from a movie not set in Austria: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1SJw9FgEnW8&list=RD1SJw9FgEnW8&start_radio=1 Now, if only the page turner would stand up and start playing a kazoo!

Strands #486 “This is for the birds” 🔵🔵🟡🔵 🔵🔵🔵🔵 Go to the new Sidekick column to comment. Leave the app, go to your browser and bookmark this. (Note what number puzzle you're doing, to match up to the correct column.) https://www.nytimes.com/spotlight/strands-sidekick

A wildly original theme!  Every time I think it's impossible to come up with something that's never been done before, someone does.  And it's so much fun!  And the theme answers are so well-chosen and so delightfully clued!  I was sorry when it was over -- which was much too soon.

I should admit to having a special affection for long, playful clues.  Sometimes I feel the longer, the better.  And I can imagine Dan -- researching and then finding his BANK STATEMENT or his GRAPHIC DETAIL -- clapping his hands and chortling to himself.  I suspect this was as much fun to make as it was to solve.

Because I also found it quite easy for a Wednesday, it's a puzzle that I would give to a very smart but inexperienced solver.  Even though it's a Wednesday, I think they'd be able to solve it, and if they could, it might hook them on crossword puzzles for life.
This was a good one. Thanks!

What a lovely, fun puzzle. The theme entries were doable, once I got the idea. Some clever, misleading clues (others have mentioned racking their brains for a Crayola colour). 
Let's have more puzzles like this. Bravo to the constructor!

P.S.: To those upset about NAVAHO -- it was clued as a variant spelling. 

P.P.S.: Happy belated Canada Day to all the Canadians out there. Have a good one, eh?

This was full of FUN FACTs, and with the exception of the wee little Natick where WWE meets "International football competition" (I assumed soccer/futbol) it was quite simple to fill in.  No pauses anywhere else.  

For anyone desiring to quibble over NAVAHO, I would remind them that 'Owhyhee' was once the accepted spelling of a Pacific Island/chain.  (My Granny had an early edition of _Eight Cousins._)  

Do you actually say NOIRS for a genre of cinema?  'Cause I wouldn't.  
I need More Puzzle!

Sorry but as someone who lives in Arizona, it is absolutely NAVAJO.  Even the eponymous county is spelled NAVAJO.  Sure, the solve was easy thanks to the cross of GRAPHIC but even googling it, the top results are all NAVAJO.  Really poor editing.

This is for all the haters of the spelling NAVAHO: I think most of us can agree that the way we normally spell the name of the Native tribe that actually calls themselves Diné is NAVAJO. However, the spelling NAVAHO does exist, and has for decades. It has never been the most common spelling, but it has been in continuous use from the 1890s onward. It had peaks in the 1900s and the 1950s, when it registered at just above half (1907) and just below half (1954) the frequency of its counterpart with a J. See the Google Ngram for details. https://tinyurl.com/mr4yc27p As you can see in the Ngram, usage of NAVAHO has trailed off considerably in the 21st century, but it's still seen occasionally. Note that the Ngram measures usage in books, so these are edited works. For words like NAVA(H/J)O that have unambiguous meanings, Ngrams are highly accurate. Also, please note that among the Diné people, it doesn't seem to cause a big uproar how we non-Natives spell the other word. And they don't seem to take much offense over it, either. Also important, you should note that the [Var.] notation, not freely given these days, is in force, telling you to look for a less common version of the word. So please tread lightly when you have an opinion that you haven't researched a little before stating it.

Anyone complaining about the H in NAVAHO would do well to remember we're just making choices about the rendering of Navajo sounds into the Latin alphabet. Of COURSE a Spanish speaker would spell it with a J, but an H is reasonable too. At Wikipedia you can view the "official" orthography that linguists use and in fact they use "h" to represent the H sound in Navajo. It is undoubtedly true that the J is more common today and the H reads as outdated, which is why the clue warranted the "Var." as others have pointed out. (And in fact using that official orthography the word Navajo is rendered "Naabeehó", so we're ALL wrong!) (And if you wonder what the people of the Navajo nation call themselves, it's "Diné".) https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navajo_language

Off-topic for today's puzzle but - I hope it's at least somewhat appropriate for 'wordplay.' Anyway - for no discernible reason - this morning I somehow thought about word that rhymes with different spellings. Kind of interesting in English. Anyway - one example: 

hotter, daughter, water, fodder.

If anyone thinks of some other examples feel free to chime in. 

I'll shut up now.
Great, fun puzzle. Perfect Wednesday!

Such a delightful puzzle! I got PUBTRIVIA immediately, but took a few extra minutes for the rest. Still, for a Tuesday, it was enormously fun to fill in. I realized the J would be an H in NAVAHO right away, thanks to the "var." When I see arguments about it, as those in this comments section, I want to say, step back people. Look what's happening in the world. Is this the hill you want to die on?

Meanwhile, when I opened my Wordle this morning, I was dismayed to see it welcoming me to continue my 1-day streak! I haven't lost a game since returning from vacation several weeks ago! Opening the archive, it seems it "lost" several games since I've been back. Yes, I emailed the team to air my sorrows, but since I am not all that competitive, it's not going to ruin my day. If I have to play them again, I'll probably just enjoy it again.

Bringing me to my ear worm of the day: Heather on the Hill, from Brigadoon.

Given the thematic entries, the grid design, and the constraints of symmetry, 17A had to be either PUBTRIVIA or HARDTRUTH. And 23A had to be either GRAPHICDETAIL or BANKSTATEMENT.

As an experience constructor, Mr. Caprera would have considered the various possible placements for these four entries *before* attempting to fill the the non-thematic portions of the grid.

I can only assume that his experience (and, perhaps, his software) suggested that PUBTRIVIA at 17A and GRAPHICDETAIL at 23A was the most promising of the four options he had.

Given that, our constructor then needs to fill 6D with something fitting the pattern ??V?H?. What would you put there? I don't have professional software and a word list on hand, but I can't imagine there are many (any?) options other than NAVAHO.

So what to do? Discard or reject the puzzle simply because it's NAVAHO (Var.) and not NAVAJO?

Maybe folks should consider how challenging it is to construct a puzzle as solid as this one.

(That said, if we had WOAH in the grid, well in that case ...)

Was fun trying to guess the themers.  I misread the [. . . first chartered money supplier . . . ] clue and kept looking for something to do with "mint".  

MINTCONDITION?   Nah.  

Nice one and thanks.
That was fun!
7 clues that are 'for short/informally/variant spelling' ... 22 proper nouns... this felt... rather forced. this deserved more time in editing.
Fun and super breezy for a Weds! Makes me worried about tomorrow’s puzz. Appreciated all the classic film references.

Here in AZ, we spell it Navajo. Combine that with "ACH" instead of "ICK", and that porn movie clue starts looking like "..APJAC". And I thought the NYT had made a move over to the... vulgar side of the vocabulary!
23A could also be clued the worst film ever made (it's on Wikipedia)

you need a place where i can complain about Connections. there are obviously some pretty massive leaps in logic if almost nobody is able to complete the puzzle. only the yellow set made any sense at all.

For anyone interested in an entertaining fictional treatment of the Dine’ People, Tony Hillerman’s Leaphorn and Chee books do a respectable job. And AMC’s Dark Winds series has a great cast, esp. Zahn McClarnon as Joe Leaphorn. It’s set in the 1970s, one of my top three favorite decades of my life.

Great puzzle!

The quibbles and quips about NAVAHO are curious to me for a couple of reasons:
In crossword lingo, variant almost always alludes to a different spelling. 
The Diné wish to be known as such. Whereas Americans use English terminology to identify those from other countries, it is a bit different here, where we have occupied the land that was once another people’s birthright. I live in New Mexico, so I know firsthand about such things. Please use Diné.
How exactly is CHER in the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame? This Iron Maiden fan wants to know. Jeez Louise, just change the name to "Stuff Jann Wenner likes."
I loved the theme and theme answers for this one! Great puzzle overall.

Where's my Pips! Where's my Pips! 
(said in a chant while I bang the table)

Jk I know it said that Pips would be gone July 1 but I'm still sad. I thought it was a fun puzzle and I did them every day! Please consider bringing them back
Next week, the Castro Theatre will only be showing noirs. They'll be playing some of my favorite noirs. Been a while since I've seen those noirs on the big screen.
For once I figured out the theme (before reading Wordplay) and it actually helped!

That was really fun. I chuckled often.

And two Sound of Music references!
NAVAHO is incorrect.  I do not need to make any other comment.

I think 29A should more accurately be clued “2014 Winter Olympics site”. Not host. I think the host more commonly means the country. I’m fine with calling it The Country Which Shall Remain Nameless, but that’s who the host would be.
I’ve never heard Tyson called kid dynamite

Here are some of my humble & silly offerings (with the number of letters in the answers):

- Did you know?! Kurdish people make up between 10-20% of the population in Turkey, Syria, Iraq and Iran (8,6)
- Did you know?! A hip-hop dancer developed a tumor on his head after repeatedly spinning on it (it was benign and removed) (8,4)
- Did you know?! The Gay and Lesbian Advocates and Defenders group has been fighting discrimination since 1978 (4,7)
- Did you know?! "Fake Plastic Trees" are used in many places as nicer-looking cell or WiFi towers (10,12)

Such a fun, engaging puzzle!  Both my husband and I got quite a few laughs out of the cluing today.  "Room for growth?" and "Creator of a lot of buzz on the music scene" really made me chuckle.  As we are heading to London in a few short days I am going to keep my eyes peeled for pubs named The Red Lion.  I hope to see a lot!  Thanks for a fun Wednesday puzzle, Dan.  I look forward to your next submission.
Fun puzzle; absolute blast to solve. Great job!

Not how you spell Navajo. I've been solving for over a year now and have never encountered "Var." meaning "a variant spelling." I got it because of the cross, but if I hadn't, how on earth was I supposed to know that the constructor misspelled it on purpose without looking it up? Even after solving it I still had to look up what "Var." meant in this context. You should've at least have the decency to not abbreviate it. It feels like a complete cop-out, and an ugly smear on an otherwise good puzzle.

Should I mention that I watched El Satario movie or is it too inappropriate here? Well, I just mentioned it. For those of you who want a review — it was… an unusual experience 😄 These days it feels more like a bad stupid comedy. But you need to watch it if you think that people in good-old-times were better and more decent than our modern society (they weren’t). Interestingly enough, you can watch it on Wikimedia Commons (I didn’t expect that). 

And yeah, it was a pretty tough puzzle for me since I’m not a native speaker, so I used Google a lot, but I have to say it was difficult even with cheating today. A bit proud of myself that I didn’t give up😄
Thanks to all who took issue with NAVAHO. It was great fun watching the regulars race from post to post to put out the fires. 🤣🤣🤣
Absolutely delightful Wednesday offering...thanks for the fun Dan!
So I’m on a three day streak after turning off hints and like many of you were unsure about 6D.

Thanks for a great Wednesday puzzle, Dan Caprera. I really enjoyed it and I agree with Sam that it was just the right amount of tricky.  It didn’t take me too long to see what was going on with the theme fill, as I got PUB TRIVIA early on, with help from crosses. I did use a J the first time for  NAVAHO, but since the clue was labeled a variant, I knew that could change and of course GRAPHIC DETAIL made that necessary. For a time I had cash STATEMENT at 50A and that SW corner was my last challenge for a time because of that mistake. As soon as I saw the KAZOO that K made all the difference. 
Looking forward to more of your puzzles, Dan. Also looking forward to a nice tricky puzzle to do tomorrow.
This was a fun puzzle. Once you realize the answers are more like puns the fun really takes off.  The answer for 53 down was very easy as it was deep enough in the puzzle that it had to be PUNNY!

As a few other commenters have said, 47D is not a "onetime fad", but a very popular game to this day. My favorite variant is Tetris Effect, which has regular tournaments. I also play Puyo Puyo Tetris 2 against various strangers on the Internet on a regular basis. And Tetris 99 whenever there's a new theme to unlock.
Fun, fun, fun!

This theme was a bit disappointing because, while you could definitely consider the FUN FACT to be a fun fact and a fact about fun, and PUB TRIVIA also worked both ways, the others didn’t. The “Did you know?!” part made no sense as a clue for BANK STATEMENT. There was the makings of a good idea here but ultimately it didn’t work.

I came for the puzzle but stayed for the drama.

Fun puzzle. I enjoyed the theme.

Maybe I got overcooked working outside for most of the day, but I breezed right past navaho without a second thought.
it's way off topic and I've been saving this forever but i can't hold out anymore. https://youtu.be/PPsevhQkn68?feature=shared
Great puzzle! Navaho threw me off but its crosses were fair enough.
I had trouble with Navajo...I found the creative license taken with the spelling to be problematic

Well, this was a true Dunning-Kruger day in the comments! 

And a perfect example of why I rarely bother posting here any more. 

Soooooo many people are soooooo wrong about something in the puzzle, and sooooooo certain that they are right. 

You can show them examples in the dictionary, in a Google ngram, etc. etc. etc. that show they are mistaken, and they STILL think they're right. 

Dunning-Kruger  the extreme. 

I think it is a perfect example of what's wrong in our society today: people so demonstrably wrong about something yet so certain they're right. 

I sure hope the NYT doesn't further dumb down the puzzles to accommodate these benighted folks. 

Back on lurk...

It sounds like someplace I have no interest in visiting!  I'm not into casinos, nightclubs or rowdy crowds.

@Bob

Right. Then Texas is a [Var.] of Tejas then. But "Texas [Var.]" doesn't sound like a catchy name.

@Mango
I have seen Navaho used, just as I've seen tipi instead of teepee, and Ojibway or Ojibwa instead of Ojibwe.

All these variants are the results of trying to express a Native language in a non-Native tongue, be it English, Spanish, or French. Some variants, such as Navaho and tipi, fade away over time. But that doesn't mean they were never used. If you read older books, you'll encounter more of these variant spellings. My favorite is Esquimaux--it just looks silly. Of course, we no longer say Eskimo either. But then, we call the Navajo Dine now, don't we?

Language changes, spellings change, and they'll continue to do so as Native people work to preserve their languages.

@heironymous Perhaps this link is posted already. I didn't see it as I glanced through the comments. https://npshistory.com/nature_notes/meve/vol4-2h.htm This discussion has occurred before. The link is to literature associated with Mesa Grande National Park. It's from 1933. My point is simply that NAVAHO is indeed a variant (anglicized) spelling of the Spanish word Navajo, which itself is apparently an adaptation of the Tewa Pueblo word navahu’u, meaning "farm fields in the valley."

@Rich in Atlanta Unless I'm missing your point--in many accents of English, none of those words would rhyme, exactly. As I speak the language, only "daughter" and "water" rhyme. "hotter" and "fodder" have the same vowel, but different (dental) consonants. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexical_set# But the four rhyme well enough to make for interesting poetry, a 20th c. sonnet, say. Speaking of sonnets, here's one by George Starbuck: Sonnet With a Different Letter at the End of Every Line O for a muse of fire, a sack of dough, Or both! O promissory notes of woe! One time in Santa Fe N.M. Ol’ Winfield Townley Scott and I … But whoa. One can exert oneself, ff, Or architect a heaven like Rimbaud, Or if that seems, how shall I say, de trop, One can at least write sonnets, a propos Of nothing save the do-re-mi-fa-sol Of poetry itself. Is not the row Of perfect rhymes, the terminal bon mot, Obeisance enough to the Great O? “Observe,” said Chairman Mao to Premier Chou, “On voyage à Parnasse pour prendre les eaux. On voyage comme poisson, incog.”

@Marlene

I think I've cracked the code for Wordle.  I don't remember when I last blew a game.  But my streak is officially 58, because I just didn't do one 59 days ago (although I immediately made it up).

I had a streak roughly double before that, but I think I've figured out what the correct moves are to always win.  At that point, it's no longer a challenge.  There are no new ways of the puzzle maker coming up with new angles to hold the experienced solver, like there are with crosswords.

Also, i don't think it's that big an accomplishment, since the Wordle Bot always tells me that about 98% of solvers get it by the sixth guess.
@Steve L I find that using the previous day’s solution as a starting guess makes it more interesting!

@Steve L To make Wordle more challenging, you might start each game with a "random" five-letter word. https://perchance.org/fiveletter And then consider yourself "victorious" only if you solve in fewer steps than the bot. That's my approach ... and I rarely win!

@Steve L

There have been 80% win days.

@Steve L

My longest streak was, I think, 138 days. But I consider it a fun game when I get it in 4 or 5 steps with few yellows, and mostly greens. Or, even with a lot of yellows. I have gotten it on the first step...boring. Or the second step. Meh. To me, there's no challenge in getting it without having to figure anything out. When the game says "Splendid!" I have to agree! 

I choose a random word every day.  Sometimes I'll choose a word I see on the news (with the captions on). Or something my husband just said to me. Other times it might be a word that is stuck in my head as a "good word," such as beast, which was really good for me. 

I find the Wordle Bot a little condescending, when it tells me I made a "good guess," when actually I worked it out carefully. Hmph.

@Marlene - Yes, I stopped using the Wordlebot after a few tries.  It was condescending on reasonable entries, given the letter clues.  They weren't "guesses", they were  certainties.  Also, the bot is able to pull up every word ever invented, and I have a fallible human brain.  Using the bot was not enjoyable or helpful.

From Wiki:

MTV Chi was a spin-off network from MTV targeted at young Chinese Americans, which ran from 2005 to 2007, as part of its MTV World division.[1][2] The network featured various styles of music such as Mando pop, Canto pop and Chinese American hip hop.[3] It broadcast in English and featured a mix of original programming with the best of MTV's International programming.

@George most of the time I think critiques on puzzles are pretty valid, but also most regular puzzle takers know that "Var." means a variant spelling. It's one of the types of clues.

@George

What did you think it meant, varnish?  Varsity?  Variegated?

I think that "Var." has been used so rarely lately that younger/newer solvers have never seen it before, but come on!  You couldn't figure it out?  Seriously?

The last time NAVAHO appeared was about 15 years ago; it was a frequent entry at one time.  Today was the first time it appeared with a "Var."  Fifteen years ago, it wasn't as much the variant that it now is.  

Pay mind to the setting of the clue: the WWII code breakers.  In that era, spelling it with an H was quite a bit more common.  Never the more common spelling, but seen often enough not to evoke the rage seen here today.  

This is a skill issue.  The clue is perfectly pitched for the answer:  NAVAHO is indeed a now-rare but once-common variant spelling, well documented during WWII, and reaching a peak around 1957, when it was about half as common as the J-version, but very much in use.

And though you didn't bring it up, others have:  yes, the  Native name for themselves is Diné; however, NAVAHO and NAVAJO are not considered slurs, and the land they are sovereign to is called the Navajo Nation, not the Diné Nation.  There have been efforts to change it, but the majority of the people prefer not to.  One reason is that Diné just means "the people," and can mean human beings in general.  The Diné are generally fine with outsiders calling them Navajo/-ho.
@George var. often means spelling variant. In fact I can't recall a time it meant something else. But these "variants" are rarely satisfying and generally just questionable.

@George
I’ve been solving crossword puzzles for 50+ years. Var. has always meant a variation from the norm spelling wise. Although it’s rare for NYT it is 100% acceptable across all crossword circles.

@BamBam, have none of you ever used a dictionary? When you look up a word that has more than one accepted spelling, it is always labeled "var" or "variant spelling". The more common spelling will be first, with the less common, but still acceptable, coming after.
@DK, if you look up these variants in a dictionary you will find that they are not questionable; they are alternative, accepted spellings. It's not a tough concept.
